Kung Fu: A philosophy in motion

By James Bithell

Neville Abbott is a master of martial arts, and trained at an ancient Shaolin temple in China. Josh Boswell finds out why he left South Africa and his Apartheid childhood behind to set up a Kung Fu academy in York. (Thumbnail credit A Taoist temple near the world famous Shaolin Monastery)

Damien Hirst: The Con Artist

Damien Hirst continues to be a divisive conceptual artist. With his new exhibition at the Tate Modern, Aggie Torrance explores why we shouldn't give up on Modern Art just yet. (Thumbnail credit Hirst with cast 'For the Love of God' which is encrusted with PS14m of diamonds. Image credit: Reuters )

Bel Ami

This dull portrayal of sexual seduction in nineteenth century Paris might be alleviated if Pattinson's acting range covered more than three faces.

Interview: Bowling for Soup

MILF's, touring and going solo: bassist Erik Chandler talks to Alex Edgerton about the band from 1994 to 2012

Is the grass really always greener?

What if Cilla Black rapped, Rush Limbaugh was the face of the Democratic election campaign, and Amy Childs won a Turner prize? It's not out of this world

Thinking Inside the Box

There are many times when 'bigger equals better'. When you make too much brownie mix and have to make a dozen extra ones. When you get an unexpected upgrade from a single to double bed. When you buy the March or September issues of fashion magazines

Mystery Plays Rewind History

The producer of York's Myster Cycle Production, Liam Evans-Ford, speaks to Celia Scruby

Best Book - Smut

'Smut' takes the form of two short stories by Northern national treasure, Alan Bennett.

Weiwei's sunflower seeds still have a continuing power, investigates Agatha Torrance

Interview: Josh T Pearson

Beardy Texan musician Josh T. Pearson talks divorce, death and divinity with Sam Briggs

Review: Portico Quartet

Though the band seemed to be playing great and enjoying themselves , the Duchess' sound setup did let them down.

Review: Redlight

Again, given Redlight's talent it is a disappointingly small crowd - but that couldn't stop the quality of all the acts shining through.

Local Spotlight: Berlin Black

There's nothing quite like the thuds of synth layered with atmospheric guitar, a groove ridden drum beat and anguished crooning, that either mean you're in Reflex or have fantastic taste in your 80s music. In this case, you'd be listening to York based post-punk band, Berlin Black.

Project X

Three High School students plan a house party in order to boost their reputation amongst their peers and improve their success with the fairer sex.

Rampart

While engaging in some scenes and even realistic in others, "Rampart" is disjointed and lacks direction even with the brilliant performance from Harrelson

A Queer Celebration

The BFI's Gay and Lesbian Film Festival has an uncertain future, Sophie Rose Walker learns

The Review. La Vecchia Scuola

As Italian restaurant addicts, the imposing white facade, pillars, and appearance of happy diners sipping red wine through the windows convinced us that this would be a safe bet

The Experiment. Lamb, leeks and chocolate sauce

By James Bithell

With Easter just round the corner, here's a dish that combines good old fashioned hearty British food (leeks, potatoes and lamb) with a savoury chocolate sauce to really wind up your housemates that have given it up for lent- but it also tastes delicious!

The Final Say.

Internet Date? Yes please.

By James Bithell

The Real Black Swan

By James Bithell

Dancers from the English National Ballet talk to Bella Foxwell and set the record straight about the enigmatic world of ballet.

The Secret Abortion Trail

By James Bithell

Irish women don't have the right to Choice. Janey Stephenson meets the charity helping them on their journey to the UK. (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Tom Witherow)

The Penal Code

By James Bithell

4 billion people worldwide can still be sentenced to death. Jenny Barnett finds out what's being done to abolish the death penalty.

Thoroughly Modern Millican

Sarah puts on, not for the first time, a very well written and skilfully performed show.

Pinter Double Bill: Moonlight and Celebration

It is certainly an acquired taste, but if one can appreciate that Pinter has not created this as a crowd pleaser then ironically I believe you can really enjoy it.

Fashion's Front Rows - A Spotters Guide

By James Bithell

Amidst the heady whirl of fashion weeks, the shows and the clothes, it is easy to forget that special spot everyone ogles at - the Front Row

Yeomen of the Guard

Although falling below expectations, Yeomen of the Guard retained the light hearted frivolity of Gilbert and Sullivan, leaving the audience with the feel-good factor.

Spamalot

This production is able to stand up as a piece of entertainment by itself...and successfully incorporates the irresistible element of a musical.

The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel

My parents loved it. But they also love to drink sherry.

Young Adult

Young Adult is an excellent film, but it's a bit too dark, a bit too intense and it sometimes labours the point.
